Invisible Wounds
nytimes_articles.abstract: SPEAKING OF SADNESS Depression, Disconnection, and the Meanings of Illness. By David A. Karp. 240 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $25.    UNLIKE people who suffer devastating illnesses that can be "documented" by numbers and pictures, people who suffer severe depression find it almost impossible to articulate their particular experiences of hell because they have  no burn marks to show for it. In his book "Speaking of Sadness: Depression, Disconnection, and the Meanings of Illness," David A. Karp contends that the phenomenology of depression is as important to study as the more commonly researched issues of incidence, etiology and treatment. A person does not just wake up one day and announce, "I am a depressed person." Each statement he makes about himself, his depression, his relationships and his future is the result of an evolutionary process in which he assumes an "illness identity" over time.

Jackie Chan, American Action Hero?
nytimes_articles.abstract:
WHENEVER JACKIE CHAN LEAVES HONG KONG TO MAKE A public appearance in Shanghai, Taipei or Tokyo, or in Kuala Lumpur, Singapore or Seoul, hundreds -- sometimes thousands -- of his fans gather in a frenzy of adoration. Last June, Chan, the martial artist, comic actor and stunt man who is Asia's biggest movie  star, flew to Los Angeles for MTV's annual Movie Awards. He was met at the airport by about 25 people. Among the signs and banners held aloft, a bright pink strip read: ALL AMERICANS LOVE JACKIE. SOME JUST DON'T KNOW IT YET. 

     Martial arts devotees and patrons of Chinatown movie houses have known to love Chan since the late 1970's. More recently, his signature blend of comedy and combat, honed over 43 films, has turned him into a cult icon among a more diverse audience, including Hollywood film makers and Generation X hipsters for  whom high-octane Hong Kong films have become required viewing. At the MTV awards, where Chan was given a Lifetime Achievement Award, Quentin Tarantino heatedly proclaimed him a cinematic virtuoso on the level of Buster Keaton (one  of Chan's acknowledged influences) and Fred Astaire.

EARNING IT;At Work, a Different Test for Drugs
nytimes_articles.abstract:
SAMUEL G. ALLEN and Darryl L. Kenyon have had their hair snipped for reasons  that have nothing to do with good grooming. The aim was to see whether they use  drugs. 

     Mr. Allen, 45, is international president of Sports Authority, a retail sporting goods chain based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., that employs almost 10,000 people. Mr. Kenyon, 30, works in Grand Rapids, Mich., as a supervisor for the Steelcase Corporation, one of the country's largest makers of office furniture. As conditions of their employment, both men had strands of hair clipped from the backs of their heads and tested for the presence of marijuana,  cocaine and other illegal drugs.

Yeltsin Surrenders to His Worst Nature
nytimes_articles.abstract:
The consequence of Boris Yeltsin's brutal attack on Pervomayskoye last week will be exactly the reverse of what the Russian President intended. The destruction of that village in Dagestan will not intimidate the Chechens but rather embolden them and their neighbors to new and broader actions. It will not consolidate Mr. Yeltsin's authority but rather isolate him still further from democratic forces in Moscow. And it will not strengthen his hand in Washington but rather highlight the impotence of Washington's past uncritical support and be the first step toward a re-evaluation of that approach. 

     Pervomayskoye taught the Chechens three lessons: First, Mr. Yeltsin has no interest in a political settlement, cannot be counted on to keep his word, and is prepared to be far more brutal to non-Russians than to ethnic Russians. The Dagestanis, who have stood aside from the Chechen fighting and were initially appalled by the seizure of hostages, have now changed sides because of the brutality of Mr. Yeltsin's actions. As a Dage-stani official told Izvestia, Mr.  Yeltsin's actions will become his "greatest mistake" and lead to a wider war in  the Caucasus.

DRIVING;Trouble SpotsA look at trouble spots you may encounter in the next week -- or month, or months -- courtesy of Transcom, an interstate transportation agency. 1. INTERSTATE 80 Lodi. The crossover from the local lanes to the express lanes is closed until further notice. 2. ROUTES 1 and 9 Essex. Southbound traffic is shifted to northbound express lanes between the Pulaski Skyway and Interstate 78. The Wilson Avenue exit is closed. Until further notice. 3. EAST HOBART GAP ROAD Essex County, between J. F. K. Parkway and Canoe Brook Drive. Road closed for bridge replacement until further notice. Detour posted. 4. ROUTE 22 Kenilworth, Union County. One eastbound lane closed at Michigan Avenue. Monday through Friday, 9 A.M. to 4 P.M., through Feb. 12. 5. ROUTE 1 Plainsboro. The Princeton-Plainsboro Road bridge is closed until Jan. 31. Use Scudders Mill Road. 6. ROUTE 1 West Windsor. Northbound shoulder lane closed between Nassau Park Boulevard and Alexander Road until further notice. Expect delays.

NEW YORKERS & CO.;The Grand Dame of Off Broadway
Trucks Getting Safer, With a Nudge From the Government
nytimes_articles.abstract:
IT may seem, based on recent news arti cles, that light trucks a category that includes pickups, vans and sport utility vehicles -- are inherently more unsafe than cars. But Federal safety statistics indicate that this is not the case, and new Government regulations promise to make trucks even safer in the next few years. 

     The tailgate latch on some of Chrysler's older mini-vans reportedly popped open in accidents. Lawsuits and safety advocates have charged that the side-saddle fuel tanks on a previous generation of General Motors pickups are fire hazards in side collisions. And Ford is battling a number of suits contending that its Bronco II sport utility vehicle is prone to rollover accidents.

Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry;The Color of Fatality
nytimes_articles.abstract: Alberto Manguel's foreword to A BLUE TALE AND OTHER STORIES (University of Chicago, $14.95), a posthumous volume by Marguerite Yourcenar, explains that the three "curiosities" collected here, written between 1927 and 1930, when the author was in her mid-20's, shed light on her artistic development and life. While fruitful critical and biographical connections can be drawn between the stories and Yourcenar's formidable oeuvre -- particularly "Memoirs of Hadrian," "Alexis" and "Oriental Tales" -- the stories also stand on their own.  As translated by Mr. Manguel, the prose of the young Yourcenar is accomplished and her vision arrestingly mature. In the first story, "A Blue Tale," European merchants set out to plunder a cave full of sapphires on a Middle Eastern island only to meet failure, death and destitution. The spare recitation and repeated use of the color blue prove to be haunting features in this fable of greed, in which a woman catches sapphires in her hair for the merchants; after she is cruelly kidnapped, her tears turn to aquamarines. In "The First Evening," initially written by Yourcenar's father and revised by her at his request, a jaded, self-absorbed man travels with his young wife to their honeymoon in Switzerland. His fear of life's banality, which engulfs him as he approaches his conjugal bed, is momentarily abated by a telegram announcing the death of his former mistress, who still preoccupies him. The last story, "An Evil Spell," further reveals Yourcenar's imaginative powers as she describes a witch hunt, set somewhere near the Mediterranean in southern France. Here a woman named Algenare is deemed to have cast an evil spell on a woman she envies. Pointing up the human need for scapegoats, Yourcenar illustrates how naming and becoming are one, as the villagers brand Algenare a witch and Algenare herself finds in the night sky "in large trembling strokes, the giant letters of the witches' alphabet." For its insight into human frailty and vice, for its language forged  with precision and nuance, this slim trio of tales is richly rewarding.   GARDNER MCFALL

nytimes_articles.headline: BACKTALK;A Hard Combination for Billiards
nytimes_articles.abstract:
The pool game is not over until Minnesota Fats says it's over. -- Paul Newman as Fast Eddie in the film "The Hustler." 

     For Rudolf Wanderone, a k a Minnesota Fats, the game is finally over. The most famous pool hustler in history died on Thursday, a day before his 83d birthday. His passing -- even more than that of the magnificent Willie Mosconi a couple of years ago -- signals the end of an era, and it comes at a particularly hectic time for the game Fatty came to symbolize.

Global Village? Not Really
nytimes_articles.abstract:
IN five months we took 17 planes, 16 trains, 2 ferries, 10 subway systems, and 8 long-distance buses; we rented 5 cars, stayed in 28 hotels, bunked in 17 private homes, and sent 151 postcards: when it was over we'd traveled from New York to New York the hard way, via Europe, India, Southeast Asia, Japan, and South America. 

     Take my word for it (or better yet that of my traveling companion, Marguerite, who had two colds and bronchitis en route): the global village has one big backyard. We were amazed not at how small the world is but at how large. We were astounded to find that what I'd cavalierly referred to as a "quick jump" from Bangkok to Tokyo turned out to be an overnight flight, and that 20 grueling bus hours separated Buenos Aires from northern Patagonia. Nonetheless, no great  mishaps awaited us in the global vastness. The worst incident of the whole trip  was when I slipped at a Buddhist temple in Bangkok and smashed my camera (which  is why we have no pictures of Japan, where we headed next, and why I strongly recommend sticking a disposable camera in your pack).

SOAPBOX;The Tax That's Tearing Clifton Apart
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THE task of financing our children's education is tearing this city apart, and we are not alone. The headlines go to the "special needs" districts like our neighbors Paterson and Passaic -- or to wealthy ones, some of which have come under fire for top-heavy administrative budgets. But for the sandwich towns, the hundreds of middle-class communities like Clifton, the property-tax way of paying for our schools has become an unacceptable burden. 

     It's true, as Governor Whitman said in her State of the State address, that the educational focus should not be simply on adding money to school budgets. "We must stop chasing dollars and start creating scholars," she said. But education costs money, and the Governor had nothing to say about redressing the  unfairness of the existing property tax system.

VOICES: VIEWPOINT;Watch the Off Season in Military Deals
nytimes_articles.abstract:
NEARLY every week, another acquisition is announced in the defense industry.  Exciting military electronics companies are favorite targets and their values are bid up to new heights in each deal. Investors, having made millions of dollars in the sector, buy into the mantra of consolidation and anxiously await even the slightest rumor or observation that may identify the next target. 

     Sounds like 1996? Yes, but if you look at the newspapers of a decade ago, you find an eerie similarity.

nytimes_articles.headline: BENEFITS
Connecticut Q&A;: Phyllis Hoppes;The Family Dealing With the Alcoholic
nytimes_articles.abstract:
ONE out of every 20 Americans, it is estimated, is an alcoholic. For their families, living in the shadow of the disease produces often profound emotional  and even physical effects. 

     "Sometimes a spouse or significant other will start to take on some of the physical symptoms of the alcoholic or addict they are living with," said Phyllis Hoppes, director of admissions at Stonington Institute, a rehabilitation center in North Stonington for substance abusers. "They start to have gastrointestinal problems, anxiety, loss of appetite, tiredness, nausea. They lose friends. It's amazing; they go through all the same symptoms the alcoholic  person is going through."

Echoes of a Vanished Hawaii
nytimes_articles.abstract:
IN Hawaiian culture, there is deep respect for mana, a spiritual force that resides in nature, the land and its people. This explains, to me, why certain places in Honolulu resonate with an ancient aura in spite of dramatic urban changes to once natural surroundings. 

     Tucked into historic valleys, hidden in high-rise or residential neighborhoods, forgotten by many residents and rarely visited by tour buses, these tranquil places remind me of a Hawaii before World War II or during the Hawaiian monarchy, eras we residents nostalgically identify as idyllic and much  more gracious than the present. The four described here are no more than a 15- to 20-minute drive from Waikiki, yet each is remniscent of a quieter time.

Another Butterfly On the Bodice
nytimes_articles.abstract:
IF THE PERIOD COSTUMES in "Angels and Insects" seem a bit over the top, there are reasons for that. One is that they were designed by Paul Brown, best known as the costume designer who worked on the recent production of Purcell's opera "King Arthur" in Paris. Another is that Philip Haas, who directed the film, gave Mr. Brown leave to use Victorian ball gowns and other outfits to echo the insect world. 

     Mr. Haas, who directed "The Music of Chance" in 1993 and wrote the screenplay for the new film with his wife, Belinda, described "Angels and Insects" as a "twisted Victorian horror story: beautiful and menacing and beguiling and uncomfortable, all at the same time."

Johnson's Focus
Mohicans Denounce Retailer in Land Fight
nytimes_articles.abstract:
WITH a tribal drum reverberating in the December wind, a small fire sending sparks into the pristine winter sky and a group of reporters surrounding his fellow Mohican tribesmen, Steve Comer drew the curtain for his take on the great American morality play. 

     In the shadow of the Catskill Mountains, Mr. Comer, the Mohican's soft-spoken Northeastern representative, referred to the 14-hour journey that seven of his tribe had taken from their reservation in Wisconsin as a historic occasion, a chance to salve centuries-old wounds.

nytimes_articles.headline: Books in Brief: Nonfiction;Stuffed Sparrows and Other Statements
nytimes_articles.abstract: The French artist Annette Messager is remarkable for many reasons: she is one of a handful of French women artists who have been exhibited internationally since the 1960's; she has addressed, with unflagging originality, feminist issues while working in a country with no coherent feminist tradition in painting; and her multimedia artworks have a push-me, pull-you ambivalence that  makes them deliciously provocative. ANNETTE MESSAGER (Los Angeles County Museum of Art/Museum of Modern Art/Abrams, paper, $24.95), the catalogue to her  first retrospective exhibition in the United States, now at the Art Institute in Chicago, offers a concise introduction to her art. Ms. Messager, whose greatest  influence is the work of the Surrealists, often works in series; photographs and taxidermized animals have been two constants of her introspective and sometimes  menacing artworks. One of her most tender yet macabre early series, "The Boarders," featured an installation of stuffed sparrows in hand-knit sweaters, which she baptized, punished and took for "walks," conflating maternal, childlike and corporal impulses. In the 70's, she tackled themes other artists pursued much later: her photo series "Voluntary Tortures," which documented women's mudpacks and plastic surgeries, anticipated the work of Jenny Saville and Orlan by nearly two decades, and she used jokes and aphorisms as a means of  ironic cultural commentary long before Richard Prince and Jenny Holzer did. Recently, Ms. Messager has combined drawing and stuffed toys in more pointedly political pieces about global issues. Written by the exhibition's curators, Sheryl Conkelton of the Museum of Modern Art and Carol S. Eliel of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, "Annette Messager" overlooks some of the artist's  quirkier early works (for "My Approaches," for example, she sat at a cafe table  and photographed businessmen's flies), and it neglects to clarify this proto-feminist artist's relationship to American feminist art of the 70's, many  of whose concerns she shared. Still, it traces the evolution of Ms. Messager's singular vision and confirms her status as one of France's most engaging post-modern artists.   Margot Mifflin

Where Music Conveys Child's Pain
nytimes_articles.abstract:
A GROUP of 5- and 6-year-olds shaking maracas crowded around Lisa Sandagata while she played the guitar. She urged the children to move closer and closer, until they were shaking the instruments inches from her face. 

     "I can let you get close because I trust you," she said. Building trust is very important to Ms. Sandagata, a certified music therapist who meets weekly with many students in the Therapeutic Support Program offered by the Southern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services.

SUNSHINE STATES;The Shimmering Jewel of La Jolla
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THE San Diego Freeway rolls along the southern California coast past miles and miles of long, flat views of beach and ocean. But driving past La Jolla, all one sees is the steep backside of a scrubby hill. It's easy to keep driving, but it would be a mistake: the hill hides one of the coast's most beautiful spots. 

     With a name believed to come from the Spanish word for "jewel," this area 12  miles north of downtown San Diego is a treasure of forested hills that roll down to stark, wind-sculptured cliffs, sandy and rocky beaches, and the bright blue Pacific. The natural beauty is startling and vast, but it can be appreciated in  just a weekend of rambling exploration. La Jolla may be a popular tourist destination and a community of 30,000, yet it is possible to feel alone and at peace here, insulated by the rush of waves over rock and the invigorating hiss of cool salt air.

Young Turks and Plain English
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Stars like Tony Bennett, Rod Stewart and Eric Clapton found new fame with "Unplugged" albums, which feature tracks uncluttered by electronic enhancements. Politicians can learn from this. Last week, a group of freshmen Republican senators led by Spence Abraham of Michigan set off from Washington on a national bus tour to take a plain-talk conservative message to the people. Call  it Conservative Young Turks, Unplugged. 

     The senators hit the heartland because recent polls show that the shine is off the Republicans' apple.  Here are three steps they should take to get back to basics.
